Subject: Modular robot morphology & gait with hyperNEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=184928113; y=3wfcWm25h_bt3eXr9vaWl3GfGR_xELjpx3UAy8Cnq36lxmwirLY
X-Yahoo-Profile: evertwh2004

Hi all,

I am involved in a modular robotics project (www.symbrion.eu), whe=
re we are developing robots that can hook onto each other to create 'organi=
sms' that consist of linked robots. The robots can manipulate the link(s), =
e.g., to lift each other. Recently, Jeff Clune (hi Jeff) introduced me to h=
yperNEAT, and it looks like just the ticket to address two issues that we h=
ave to tackle. So here I am, excited newbie and all.

First, I want to try =
and use hyperNEAT to evolve gaits for organisms with pre-defined shapes (e.=
g., spiders, snakes). The idea is to develop a single genome that determine=
s the weights for neural nets in each of the individual robots that make up=
 the organism, so I would expect to pass the coordinates of nodes within th=
e individual NN, but also about the location of the individual in the organ=
ism (possibly related to some central node or whatever).

The next step wil=
l be to use hyperNEAT's CPPNs to evolve morphologies for organisms. I'm thi=
nking of a 3D grid where the CPPN assigns some value to each cell which def=
ines, according to some threshold, whether a robot goes in that spot or not=
. The fitness of the CPPN would be the level of success in evolving a gait =
for the resulting shape as described above. Another method of combining mor=
phology and gait development would be to interleave them in some way (waves=
 hands).

So...does that sound like a good plan, are there any pointers to =
related work? Do's and don'ts? Expressions of interest, ridicule or awe?

T=
IA,

Evert Haasdijk
VU Amsterdam
